# About This Lab
**Objective:** To become familiar with how files are added to and removed from HDFS and how to view files in HDFS.
**File locations:**
**Successful outcome:** You will have added and deleted several files and folders in HDFS.
**Before you begin:**
**Related lessons:** The Hadoop Distributed File System (HDFS)

paragraphs.text:
%md
# Lab
---

msg.data: Lab

paragraphs.title: 1 - View the hdfs dfs command

paragraphs.text:
%md
Notice that the usage contains options for performing file system tasks in HDFS, like copying files from a local folder into HDFS, retrieving a file from HDFS,
copying and moving files around, and making and removing directories. 
In this lab, you will perform these commands, and many others, to help you become comfortable with working with HDFS.

msg.data:
Notice that the usage contains options for performing file system tasks in HDFS, like copying files from a local folder into HDFS, retrieving a file from HDFS,
copying and moving files around, and making and removing directories.
In this lab, you will perform these commands, and many others, to help you become comfortable with working with HDFS.

paragraphs.title: 2 - View the content of the zeppelin user directory in HDFS

paragraphs.text:
%md
Enter the following command to view the contents of the user’s zeppelin directory in HDFS, which is /user/zeppelin
~~~
hdfs dfs -ls /user/zeppelin
hdfs dfs -ls
~~~

msg.data:
Enter the following command to view the contents of the user’s zeppelin directory in HDFS, which is /user/zeppelin

hdfs dfs -ls /user/zeppelin
hdfs dfs -ls

paragraphs.title: 3 - View the content of the root directory and the user directory in HDFS

paragraphs.text:
%md
**Important**

Notice how adding the / in the -ls command caused the contents of the root folder to display, but leaving off the / showed the contents of /user/zeppelin, which is the default prefix if you leave off the leading / on any of the hadoop commands (assuming the command is run by the “zeppelin” user).

msg.data:
Important

Notice how adding the / in the -ls command caused the contents of the root folder to display, but leaving off the / showed the contents of /user/zeppelin, which is the default prefix if you leave off the leading / on any of the hadoop commands (assuming the command is run by the “zeppelin” user).

paragraphs.title: 4 - Create a directory named test in HDFS

paragraphs.text:
%md
Enter the following command to create a directory named test in HDFS:
~~~
hdfs dfs -mkdir test
~~~

msg.data:
Enter the following command to create a directory named test in HDFS:

hdfs dfs -mkdir test

paragraphs.title: 5 - Verify that the folder was created successfully
6 - Create a couple of subdirectories for test

paragraphs.text:
%md
Create a couple of subdirectories for test:
~~~
hdfs dfs -mkdir test/test1
hdfs dfs -mkdir -p test/test2/test3
~~~
Notice how the -p command can be used to create multiple directories. The second command above will fail if you omit the -p.

msg.data:
Create a couple of subdirectories for test:

hdfs dfs -mkdir test/test1
hdfs dfs -mkdir -p test/test2/test3

Notice how the -p command can be used to create multiple directories. The second command above will fail if you omit the -p.

paragraphs.title: 7 - View the contents of /user/zeppelin

paragraphs.text:
%md
Notice you only see the test directory.
~~~
hdfs dfs -ls /user/zeppelin
hdfs dfs -ls 
~~~

msg.data:
Notice you only see the test directory.

hdfs dfs -ls /user/zeppelin
hdfs dfs -ls

paragraphs.title: 8 - View the contents of /user/zeppelin recursively

paragraphs.text:
%md
Notice you only see the test directory. To recursively view the contents of a folder, use -ls -R:
~~~
hdfs dfs -ls -R
~~~

msg.data:
Notice you only see the test directory. To recursively view the contents of a folder, use -ls -R:

hdfs dfs -ls -R

paragraphs.title: 9 - Delete an empty directory test1 and delete test recursively

paragraphs.text:
%md
Delete the test2 folder (and recursively, its sub-contents) using the -rm -R command:
~~~
hdfs dfs -rmdir latin/test2
hdfs dfs -rm -r test
~~~

msg.data:
Delete the test2 folder (and recursively, its sub-contents) using the -rm -R command:

hdfs dfs -rmdir latin/test2
hdfs dfs -rm -r test

paragraphs.title: 10 - Confirm the deletion of the directory

paragraphs.text:
%md
**Note**

Notice Hadoop created a .Trash folder for the zeppelin user and moved the deleted content there. The .Trash folder empties automatically after a configured amount of time.

msg.data:
Note

Notice Hadoop created a .Trash folder for the zeppelin user and moved the deleted content there. The .Trash folder empties automatically after a configured amount of time.

paragraphs.text:
%md
We have downloaded some files on your local file system as part of this lab setup.
We fill use them to test the upload to HDFS.

msg.data:
We have downloaded some files on your local file system as part of this lab setup.
We fill use them to test the upload to HDFS.

paragraphs.title: 11 - Check the content of /var/data/latin/latin.txt
paragraphs.text: %sh

paragraphs.title: 12 - Make a HDFS directory latin and copy latin.txt into it

paragraphs.text:
%md
Run the following -put command to copy data.txt into the test folder in HDFS:
~~~
hdfs dfs -mkdir latin
hdfs dfs -put /var/data/latin/latin.txt latin/
~~~

msg.data:
Run the following -put command to copy data.txt into the test folder in HDFS:

hdfs dfs -mkdir latin
hdfs dfs -put /var/data/latin/latin.txt latin/

paragraphs.title: 13 - Verify that the file is in HDFS by listing the contents of latin
14 - Make a HDFS directory rome/men and copy latin.txt

paragraphs.text:
%md
Now copy the data.txt file in test to another folder in HDFS using the -cp command:
~~~
hdfs dfs -mkdir -p rome/men
hdfs dfs -cp latin/latin.txt rome/men/ceaser.txt
~~~

msg.data:
Now copy the data.txt file in test to another folder in HDFS using the -cp command:

hdfs dfs -mkdir -p rome/men
hdfs dfs -cp latin/latin.txt rome/men/ceaser.txt

paragraphs.title: 15 - Verify that the file is in both places by using the -ls -R command
16 - Now delete the rome directory using the -rm command with skipTrash

paragraphs.text:
%md
The option fs.trash.interval controls how frequently the NameNode will glean files in .Trash. The default is 360 mins or 6 hours.
You can delete a file by skipping the trash:
~~~
hdfs dfs -rm -r -skipTrash rome
~~~

msg.data:
The option fs.trash.interval controls how frequently the NameNode will glean files in .Trash. The default is 360 mins or 6 hours.
You can delete a file by skipping the trash:

hdfs dfs -rm -r -skipTrash rome

paragraphs.title: 17 - View the contents of a file in HDFS

paragraphs.text:
%md
You can use the -cat command to view text files in HDFS. 
Be warned this will display all of the data, even it is terabytes in size.
Enter the following command to view the contents of data.txt:
~~~
hdfs dfs -cat latin/latin.txt
~~~

msg.data:
You can use the -cat command to view text files in HDFS.
Be warned this will display all of the data, even it is terabytes in size.
Enter the following command to view the contents of data.txt:

hdfs dfs -cat latin/latin.txt

paragraphs.title: 18 - You can also use the -tail command to view the end of a file
19 - Determine how many times lines contain the Latin word semper

paragraphs.text:
%md
You can use any shell expansion with the hdfs command. 

~~~
hdfs dfs -cat latin/latin.txt | grep semper
hdfs dfs -cat latin/latin.txt | grep semper | wc -l
~~~

msg.data:
You can use any shell expansion with the hdfs command.

hdfs dfs -cat latin/latin.txt | grep semper
hdfs dfs -cat latin/latin.txt | grep semper | wc -l

paragraphs.title: 20 - Getting the latin.txt file from HDFS

paragraphs.text:
%md
See if you can figure out how to use the get command to copy latin/latin.txt from HDFS into your local /tmp folder.

msg.data: See if you can figure out how to use the get command to copy latin/latin.txt from HDFS into your local /tmp folder.

paragraphs.title: 21 - Put all of the book files into the books folder in HDFS
22 - Run a getmerge command

paragraphs.text:
%md
You should now have many files in books.
Run the following getmerge command:
~~~
hdfs dfs -getmerge book /tmp/merged.txt
~~~

msg.data:
You should now have many files in books.
Run the following getmerge command:

hdfs dfs -getmerge book /tmp/merged.txt

paragraphs.title: 23 - Display the contents of the /tmp/merged.txt
paragraphs.text:
%md
Put data.txt into /user/root in HDFS, giving it a blocksize of 1,048,576 bytes.  
**Hint:** The blocksize is defined using the dfs.blocksize property on the command line.

%md
What did the previous command do? Did you open the file merged.txt to see what happened?

msg.data: What did the previous command do? Did you open the file merged.txt to see what happened?

paragraphs.title: 24 - Make a directory for nyse and load the nyse_daily_price.csv while changing the blocksize to 2 megabytes
paragraphs.text: %sh

%md
Create small HDFS data blocks for exercise purposes
Create the nyse directory
~~~
cd ~/data/nyse
hdfs dfs -mkdir nyse
~~~
Learn about the -D option for dfs.blocksize

~~~
hdfs dfs -D dfs.blocksize=2097152 -put nyse_daily_prices.csv nyse
hdfs dfs -ls nyse
~~~

msg.data:
Create small HDFS data blocks for exercise purposes
Create the nyse directory

cd ~/data/nyse
hdfs dfs -mkdir nyse

Learn about the -D option for dfs.blocksize

hdfs dfs -D dfs.blocksize=2097152 -put nyse_daily_prices.csv nyse
hdfs dfs -ls nyse

paragraphs.title: 25 - Run hdfs fsck on the directory nyse

paragraphs.text:
%md
The hdfs fsck command communicates directly with the NameNode. 
It will provide you invaluable information about the files and the blocks.
Run the following fsck command on data.txt:
~~~
hdfs fsck nyse -files
hdfs fsck nyse -files -locations
hdfs fsck nyse -files -locations -blocks
~~~

paragraphs.title: 2 - View the content of the zeppelin user directory in HDFS
paragraphs.text:
%sh
hdfs dfs -ls /user/zeppelin
hdfs dfs -ls

paragraphs.title: 3 - View the content of the root directory and the user directory in HDFS
paragraphs.text:
%sh
hdfs dfs -ls /
hdfs dfs -ls /user

paragraphs.title: 4 - Create a directory named test in HDFS
paragraphs.text:
%sh
hdfs dfs -mkdir test

paragraphs.title: 5 - Verify that the folder was created successfully
paragraphs.text:
%sh
hdfs dfs -ls

paragraphs.title: 6 - Create a couple of subdirectories for test
paragraphs.text:
%sh
hdfs dfs -mkdir test/test1
hdfs dfs -mkdir -p test/test2/test3

paragraphs.title: 7 - View the contents of /user/zeppelin
paragraphs.text:
%sh
hdfs dfs -ls

paragraphs.title: 8 - View the contents of /user/zeppelin recursively
paragraphs.text:
%sh
hdfs dfs -ls -R

paragraphs.title: 9 - Delete an empty directory test1 and delete test recursively
paragraphs.text:
%sh
hdfs dfs -rmdir test/test1
hdfs dfs -rm -R test

paragraphs.title: 10 - Confirm the deletion of the directory
paragraphs.text:
%sh
hdfs dfs -ls -R

paragraphs.title: 11 - Check the content of /var/data/latin/latin.txt
paragraphs.text:
%sh
cat /var/data/latin/latin.txt

paragraphs.title: 12 - Make a HDFS directory latin and copy latin.txt into it
paragraphs.text:
%sh
hdfs dfs -mkdir latin
hdfs dfs -put /var/data/latin/latin.txt latin/

paragraphs.title: 13 - Verify that the file is in HDFS by listing the contents of latin
paragraphs.text:
%sh

hdfs dfs -ls latin

paragraphs.title: 14 - Make a HDFS directory rome/men and copy latin.txt
paragraphs.text:
%sh
hdfs dfs -mkdir -p rome/men
hdfs dfs -cp latin/latin.txt rome/men/ceaser.txt

paragraphs.title: 15 - Verify that the file is in both places by using the -ls -R command
paragraphs.text:
%sh
hdfs dfs -ls -R

paragraphs.title: 16 - Now delete the rome directory using the -rm command with skipTrash
paragraphs.text:
%sh
hdfs dfs -rm -r -skipTrash rome

paragraphs.title: 17 - View the contents of a file in HDFS
paragraphs.text:
%sh
hdfs dfs -cat latin/latin.txt

paragraphs.title: 18 - You can also use the -tail command to view the end of a file
paragraphs.text:
%sh
hdfs dfs -tail latin/latin.txt

paragraphs.title: 19 -  Determine how many times lines contain the Latin word semper
paragraphs.text:
%sh
hdfs dfs -cat latin/latin.txt | grep semper
hdfs dfs -cat latin/latin.txt | grep semper | wc -l

paragraphs.title: 19 - Getting the latin.txt file from HDFS
paragraphs.text:
%sh
hdfs dfs -get latin/latin.txt /tmp/
ls /tmp/data*

paragraphs.title: 20 - Put the file small_blocks.txt into the test folder in HDFS
paragraphs.text:
%sh
hdfs dfs -put small_blocks.txt test/

paragraphs.title: 21 - Put all of the book files into the books folder in HDFS
paragraphs.text:
%sh
cd /var/data/books
ls 
hdfs dfs -mkdir books
hdfs dfs -put *txt books/

paragraphs.title: 22 - Run a getmerge command
paragraphs.text:
%sh
hdfs dfs -getmerge books /tmp/merged.txt

%md
**Answer:** The two files that were in the test folder in HDFS were merged into a single file and stored on the local file system.

msg.data: Answer: The two files that were in the test folder in HDFS were merged into a single file and stored on the local file system.

paragraphs.title: 22 - Specify the Block Size
paragraphs.text:
%sh
hdfs dfs -D dfs.blocksize=1048576 -put data.txt test/data3.txt

paragraphs.title: 23 - Display the contents of the /tmp/merged.txt file
paragraphs.text:
%sh
less /tmp/merged.txt

paragraphs.title: 24 - Make a directory for nyse and load the nyse_daily_price.csv while changing the blocksize to 2 megabytes
paragraphs.text:
%sh
cd ~/data/nyse
hdfs dfs -mkdir nyse

hdfs dfs -D dfs.blocksize=2097152 -put nyse_daily_prices.csv nyse
hdfs dfs -ls nyse

paragraphs.title: 25 - Run hdfs fsck on the directory nyse
paragraphs.text:
%sh
hdfs fsck nyse -files
hdfs fsck nyse -files -locations
hdfs fsck nyse -files -locations -blocks

%md
**Answer:** The file should be broken down into nine blocks

msg.data: Answer: The file should be broken down into nine blocks
